- Okay, so as we get started,
 there's something

that I want to
get out of the way.

Um, you're- I mean, there are no-

dah dah dah dah dah - and there's

So I wonder if you can just

- Yeah, thank you.

I come from the minimum-wage
working world of the "1870s."

Uh, and luckily, I got into punk rock,
which made music

possible for a guy like me, 'cause
I couldn't hold a note or play guitar.

But I could express myself, and so
punk rock gave me that opportunity.

I got into a band called Black Flag,
and kind of went forth from there,

coming from wearing an apron,
scooping ice cream,

tearing movie theatre tickets,
parking cars.

I'm not putting down any of that but
that's kind of what I was trained for,

not what I
wanted to do with my life.

And so, ever since 1981,
I just show up and say yes to things.

Like, "Hey, wanna be in a movie?"
Yeah. "Can you act?" Yes.

(crowd laughing)
"Hey, wanna be in a documentary?"

Sure, about what? I said yes before
I even knew what it was about.

"No, no, we want you to
make the documentary."

Oh! Fine.
"You wanna write a screenplay?"

Yeah.
"Can you write a screenplay?" Sure.
And I did. The film is out this year.

Um, so I just say yes to things
because it's better than saying no,

it's better than being bored,
but as far as my qualifications,

I'm really good at spending
way too much time on the Internet

looking at records, sleeping late
and eating way too much at one time.
(laughter)

- You say that anger
really helped you, uh,

figure yourself out as a teenager
and build your sense of self.

I'm wondering if you can talk a
little bit about that, what it was like

growing up in a very different time
in Washington -

from what I understand,
a very segregated place.

- I was a child of the 1960s
in Washington, D.C.

As you know, the White House
and all the trouble starts in America.

It's also a beautiful city,
very, very small.

But it's also very racially divided,
and the racial tension in the 60s-

As a boy going to school
in 1967 or 1968,

it's mostly black kids
I'm going to school with.

White neighborhood,
black kids bussed in.

So I get called "cracker" and "bama."
which I've never understood.

"Whitey". I'm being pushed around for
my skin colour. It's terrifying.
And I don't mean to be crass,

I don't know if
you've ever been unable to

hold your bladder,
you've been so scared - whish!

If it has ever happened to you,
it's uncontrollable.

And the kids would come up
and go like this.

I'd just piss my pants.
I don't know how else to say it.

I was so scared, trembling, 'cause
some kid had his fist up to my face.

"Hey, look! White boy's pissin'."
And you just feel like-

You're mortified. You go back
into school with your pant-

You can't go home and change.
And everyone's laughing.

And when you're 7,
that's like the end of your life.

And that was racial tension
in Washington.

I'd come crying to my mother,
"Why doesn't this boy like me?"

And my mom had to make me understand
civil rights and racism

as a very little boy,
and it makes you scared.

Thankfully, I never harboured
any racial sentiment

'cause my mom schooled me right,
but it was a tense place to grow up.
And I went to a prep school as a kid,

with these kind of
rich kids out in the suburbs.

I was a middle-class kid from the
city and they didn't understand me.

I didn't understand them. I was high

And so my grades were awful.

It's a 13-mile, 20-mile schlep

into this sheetrock
nightmare of mediocrity.

And I go back to a city where
they're throwing rocks at your head,
trying to take your bike.

And so, that made me
very angry and very confused.

So I had to figure out,
what can I do, what am I good at?

And apparently, as far as my father
would tell me, nothing really.

And as far as my teachers told me,
nothing really. So I was very angry.

And finally, with punk rock,

Joe Strummer informed me
why I was angry.

The Ramones taught me

not get invited to the party 'cause

(crowd chuckling)
So it's with punk rock that I said,

"Oh! I have- I got people.
I got a tribe.
And my life has a soundtrack."

And I realized I was an angry

And I started to focus it

Like, "I'll give you 40 hours a week

"Give me 60, and in 6 weeks,

And whenever I see Steve,

I was living in my car -

"Henry, you can call me Steve."

"I can't do that, sir!"

'Cause he trusted me with his money,

I know how to do this. I can do
this."

He's like, "Well, if you screw up,

And it ended up being, I ran his
store.

And so-
But it was anger that said,

"I'll be here all damn week.

I fired the staff and rehired a bunch

And it- out of anger.
Like, "I'll be back in 4 hours to run

this $3.75-an-hour job

And then I joined Black Flag.

And I thought
I was a hardworking person.

You'd see Greg Ginn

Like, "Greg, you're still

"I don't know."

"Greg, when was

"Uh, do we have a shower?"

The guy was like,
"We're not gonna be stopped."

Like, you're a very calm,

(crowd laughing)
I can't help it.

- You're focused.
- I'm sweating, man! And so...

(crowd laughing)
But I'm like this going to the airport.
Like... 10 miles out.

(chuckling)
And so-

But it's anger
that has informed, kind of, my life

and, unflatteringly,
a sense of vengeance.

Every damn person
who said I wouldn't be anything,
I'm crushing them every day.

Everybody I had to endure
in any band I was in,
every day into a powder - yeah.

(applause)
Thank you.
And I wish them no ill.
I just wish to shine brighter.

And if it burns my body to a crisp,

And, uh, so,
